bestBHT.bht: Paul's nephew, who may have been residing in Jerusalem for his education, likely obtained information about the conspiracy from the schools and promptly acted upon it. Paul charged him to keep this matter secret, employing a change in construction from indirect to direct format, which is a common feature in the New Testament. It was wise for Paul to conceal the plot's discovery, as the conspirators would have taken different actions if they had known their plan had been exposed.

Jamieson-Fausset-Brown: Paul's sister's son—If he was at this time residing at Jerusalem for his education, like Paul himself, he may have got at the schools those hints of the conspiracy on which he so promptly acted.
Archibald T. Robertson: Indirect command (oratio obliqua) after παραγγειλας (charging) with first aorist active infinitive of εκλαλεω (in ancient Greek, but here only in N.T.), but construction changed to direct in rest of the sentence (oratio recta) as in Acts 1:4.
This change is common in the N.T. (Robertson, Grammar, p. 1047).
John Gill: After he had the account from him, and was master of the whole affair.
It was a right and wise thing to conceal this matter, that the men might go on with their designs.
For otherwise, should it have been known that their plot was discovered, they would have entered upon new measures.
